sheldonScale.description: The Sheldon scale (1-70) is the internationally recognized standard for coin grading

FR-2.name: Fair
FR-2.description: Mostly worn smooth but type is identifiable

AG-3.name: About Good
AG-3.description: Very heavily worn, outline visible, some detail

G-4.name: Good
G-4.description: Heavily worn, design visible but faint in spots

G-6.name: Good
G-6.description: Heavily worn, design clear, flat in spots

VG-8.name: Very Good
VG-8.description: Well worn, main features clear but flat

VG-10.name: Very Good
VG-10.description: Well worn, design clear, some detail visible

F-12.name: Fine
F-12.description: Moderate to heavy even wear, all lettering visible

F-15.name: Fine
F-15.description: Moderate even wear, some high points flat

VF-30.name: Choice Very Fine
VF-30.description: Light to moderate even wear, all major features sharp

VF-35.name: Choice Very Fine
VF-35.description: Light even wear, all lettering and major features sharp

EF-45.name: Choice Extremely Fine
EF-45.description: Light wear on high points, all design details sharp

AU-50.name: About Uncirculated
AU-50.description: Trace wear on high points, half of mint luster present

AU-53.name: About Uncirculated
AU-53.description: Obvious wear on high points, 50%+ mint luster

AU-55.name: Choice About Uncirculated
AU-55.description: Slight wear on high points, 75%+ mint luster

AU-58.name: Choice About Uncirculated
AU-58.description: Slightest trace of wear, nearly full luster

MS-60.name: Mint State Basal
MS-60.description: No wear, weak strike, heavy marks possible

MS-61.name: Mint State
MS-61.description: No wear, weak strike, multiple abrasions

MS-62.name: Mint State
MS-62.description: No wear, more abrasions than MS-63

MS-63.name: Choice Mint State
MS-63.description: No wear, moderate contact marks, hairlines visible

MS-64.name: Choice Mint State
MS-64.description: No wear, few obvious marks, good eye appeal

MS-65.name: Gem Mint State
MS-65.description: No wear, moderate marks, strong luster, above average eye appeal

MS-66.name: Gem Mint State
MS-66.description: No wear, minimal marks, full luster, exceptional eye appeal

MS-67.name: Superb Gem Mint State
MS-67.description: No wear, virtually flawless, outstanding eye appeal

MS-68.name: Superb Gem Mint State
MS-68.description: No wear, nearly perfect, very sharp strike

PF-60.name: Proof
PF-60.description: Proof finish, heavy hairlines and marks

morgan-dollar.name: Morgan Dollar

obverseWearPoints.description: Liberty's cheek is the primary focal point. First to show wear as smoothing and loss of texture. In MS grades, should have full luster and no flattening.
Hair directly above the ear shows wear early. Look for separation of hair strands. AU coins show slight friction here.
Hair above the forehead and eye. In EF, shows slight wear. In VF, displays wide flat areas.
Edges of cotton leaves flatten with wear. Check for detail in the cotton blossoms.
High upper fold of cap shows trace wear in AU grades.

reverseWearPoints.description: Center of eagle's breast shows wear first. In VF, almost all feathers gone from breast.
Wing edges near shoulder retain luster longest. Tips wear first.
Tops of legs show wear in AU and lower grades.
Eagle's talons flatten with wear. In AU, slight trace of wear on talons.

gradeDistinctions.MS-65+: Nearly mark-free, especially on cheek and left obverse field. Full cartwheel luster.
gradeDistinctions.MS-63-64: Some marks visible but none particularly heavy or distracting.
gradeDistinctions.MS-60-62: Heavily bag-marked, but no wear. Full luster present.
gradeDistinctions.AU-58: Slightest wear on hair above ear and eagle breast. Most luster remains.
gradeDistinctions.AU-50: Traces of wear on cheek, hair, breast. 3/4 of luster present.
gradeDistinctions.EF-40: Light wear on hair and cheek. Eagle breast high points lightly worn.
gradeDistinctions.VF-20: Hair above forehead has flat areas. Breast feathers mostly gone.
gradeDistinctions.F-12: Hair merged with forehead. Eagle outline visible.
gradeDistinctions.G-4: Liberty outlined. Date and lettering visible.

morgan-dollar.gradingWeight: Two-thirds of grading weight given to obverse. Cheek and hair are critical.

peace-dollar.name: Peace Dollar

obverseWearPoints.description: Hair just above the forehead shows wear first. Look for separation of strands.
Hair bun at back of head. Loose knot should have full luster in MS grades.
Hair by cheek is a high point prone to early wear.
Neck line above the date exposed to early circulation wear.

reverseWearPoints.description: High point of eagle's wing on reverse shows wear first.
Where wing meets leg is a key wear checkpoint.
Top of right shoulder of eagle. Must retain mint luster in MS grades.
Outer edge of left wing should retain texture and fine design lines.

gradeDistinctions.MS-65+: Slight defects only. Well-struck with average or better luster. No marks in focal areas.
gradeDistinctions.MS-60-64: Full luster but may have stains, marks, or abrasions.
gradeDistinctions.AU-55-58: Slight trace of wear. Most mint luster present.
gradeDistinctions.AU-50: Some mint luster remains. High points show slight wear.
gradeDistinctions.EF-40: Light even wear on highest areas. Silver grey sheen replaces luster.
gradeDistinctions.VF-20: Hairlines over brow worn slightly. Wing feathers visible but faint.
gradeDistinctions.F-12: Major details heavily worn. Hair and feathers appear flat.
gradeDistinctions.G-4: Well-worn eagle outline without visible feathers.

specialConsiderations.1921HighRelief: Struck in high relief. Often displays flatness on hairline that is NOT wear. Must examine other areas to grade properly.
specialConsiderations.strikeVsWear: Perhaps no other series has such a high percentage of specimens that are almost, but not quite, uncirculated. Distinguishing weak strike from wear is critical.

peace-dollar.gradingTip: Look for fine lines or luster breaks as evidence of rub vs strike weakness.

obverseWearPoints.description: First signs of wear appear on Liberty's left leg. Key area for AU grading.
Liberty's left breast shows wear early. Should be outlined in VF.
Liberty's left hand often weak due to metal flow, not wear.
Separation of hair from forehead is key for EF grade.

reverseWearPoints.description: Eagle's breast feathers flatten with wear. Key reverse checkpoint.
Eagle's left leg shows wear in AU and lower grades.
Upper edges of feathers wear first. In VF, many outer feathers blur together.

gradeDistinctions.MS-65+: Full luster, minimal marks. Liberty and eagle should be nearly mark-free.
gradeDistinctions.MS-60-64: No wear, full luster. Contact marks common due to high relief design.
gradeDistinctions.AU-58: Light wear on left leg and left breast only.
gradeDistinctions.AU-50: Collar visible. High points worn on top. Most luster present.
gradeDistinctions.VF-35: Left breast almost completely outlined. Eagle breast and leg have little detail.
gradeDistinctions.F-15: Gap between breasts creates 'hook' appearance. Inner wing feathers clear.
gradeDistinctions.F-12: Stars above arm visible though flattened.

specialConsiderations.1920sIssues: 1920s coins often appear worn despite excellent condition with full luster.
specialConsiderations.sfMintIssues: San Francisco coins from 1930s-40s may also appear worn when uncirculated.
specialConsiderations.highRelief: Figure of Liberty very susceptible to contact marks from other coins.

saint-gaudens-double-eagle.name: Saint-Gaudens Double Eagle

obverseWearPoints.description: Liberty's breast is highest point. Shows wear first. Most marks occur here.
Liberty's knee is key wear point. Should be sharp in AU and above.
Trace wear visible on nose in AU grades.
Marks can hide within folds of Liberty's gown.

reverseWearPoints.description: Eagle's wing shows wear in circulated grades.
Eagle's breast feathers worn in lower grades.

gradeDistinctions.MS-65+: Minimal marks on breast and knee. Full luster and exceptional eye appeal.
gradeDistinctions.MS-63: Some blemishes in focal areas. Luster may not be as prominent.
gradeDistinctions.MS-60: Full luster but may look unappealing with heavy marks across surfaces.
gradeDistinctions.AU-55-58: Trace wear on nose, breast, and knee. Eagle's wing shows slight wear.
gradeDistinctions.EF-40: Eagle's left wing and breast feathers worn. Wear below knee visible.

saint-gaudens-double-eagle.gradingWeight: Marks on date, mintmark, or Liberty's face weigh more heavily than marks in protected areas.

obverseWearPoints.description: Just under the eye, the cheek is highest point. Wear shows as color change and smoothing of texture.
Hair strands should remain bold in EF and higher.
Long feather at back of head begins to merge with hair in F grade.
Braid detail can be weak from strike, not just wear.

reverseWearPoints.description: Buffalo's horn is CRITICAL. Full horn = VF or better. Base only = F. Gone = G or below.
Fur details on head and shoulder wear progressively.
Tail visibility helps determine grade.

gradeDistinctions.MS-65+: Full mint luster. No wear on cheek or any high points.
gradeDistinctions.EF-40: Hair strands bold. Most fur details remain. Horn complete with tip defined.
gradeDistinctions.VF-20: Hair and cheek show considerable flatness. Partial feather detail. Horn point visible.
gradeDistinctions.F-12: Feather merging with hair. Upper half of horn missing but strong base visible.
gradeDistinctions.G-4: Hair, cheek, and feathers blended. Horn completely missing.

specialConsiderations.strikeIssues: Denver and San Francisco mints 1917-27 often indistinct on high points. Grading becomes challenging.
specialConsiderations.hornAnomaly: Many mint state coins lack fully visible horn! VF-20 standard now notes 'Point of horn not always visible.'

obverseWearPoints.description: Hair above Liberty's ear shows wear first. Critical at every grade.
Wing tips should be sharp and well-defined in high grades.
Cheek area shows wear in circulated grades.

reverseWearPoints.description: Center horizontal bands on fasces are KEY. High profile means quick wear.
Two crossing diagonal bands must show for VF/EF. Show only slight wear in EF.
Clarity of vertical sticks confirms strike quality and grade. Half visible = G.

gradeDistinctions.MS-65+FB: Full Bands designation. Central bands completely separated with no breaks or bridges.
gradeDistinctions.MS-65+: No wear. Strong luster. Minor hairlines acceptable.
gradeDistinctions.AU-50-58: Trace wear on hair and wing tips. Bands may be flat from strike.
gradeDistinctions.EF-40: Light wear on hair. Diagonal bands show only slight wear.
gradeDistinctions.VF-20: Diagonal bands must show. Some flatness acceptable.
gradeDistinctions.F-12: All sticks defined. Diagonal bands worn nearly flat.
gradeDistinctions.G-4: One-half of sticks discernible in fasces.

fullBandsDesignation.description: PCGS Full Bands (FB) requires central horizontal bands completely separated, no breaks, bridges, or interruptions.
fullBandsDesignation.eligibility: Generally MS-60 and above. AU-50 allowed for 1916-D, 1942/1, and 1942/1-D.
fullBandsDesignation.note: Even minor connection or abrasion in bands prevents FB designation.

specialConsiderations.strikeVsWear: San Francisco and mid-1920s often show weak bands from poor strike, NOT wear. Check luster uniformity to distinguish.

obverseWearPoints.description: Lincoln's cheekbone shows wear early. Key area for grading.
Jaw and cheek should be separated in F grade and above.
Hair above ear shows progressive wear. Curls visible in VF.
About 1/3 of ear present in F-12 grade.

reverseWearPoints.description: Wheat stalk lines are primary reverse indicator. Check separation of parallel lines.

reverseWearPoints.wheatTips: Tips of wheat stalks show wear in AU grades.

gradeDistinctions.MS-65+: Full red or red-brown color. No wear. Exceptional luster.
gradeDistinctions.AU-58: Minimal abrasion on cheekbone and jaw. Wheat tips show minimal wear.
gradeDistinctions.AU-55: Trace wear on highest point of jaw. Wheat stalks show trace wear.
gradeDistinctions.EF-40: Slight wear on hair, cheek, and jaw. Wheat stalk lines clearly defined. Half of luster remains.
gradeDistinctions.VF-20: Hair curls visible. Jaw and cheek smooth but defined. Wheat line separation clear.
gradeDistinctions.F-12: About 2/3 of wheat lines show. Jawline and cheekbone take shape.
gradeDistinctions.VG-8: 1/3 of wheat lines show. Hint of jawline and cheekbone.
gradeDistinctions.G-4: Half of lines show in wheat heads. Hair outline only.

colorDesignations.BN: Brown - Less than 5% red color remaining

signs: Microscopic scratches or hairline marks visible under magnification
Unnatural brightness or color that seems 'off'
Incuse parallel lines visible when rotating coin
Harsh, bright appearance inconsistent with age
cleaning.gradingImpact: Cleaned coins receive 'Details' grade from PCGS/NGC rather than numeric grade. Value typically 40-70% less than uncleaned equivalent.

types.dipped: Chemical cleaning, often leaves coin bright but strips natural toning
types.wiped: Cloth or abrasive cleaning leaves fine parallel lines
types.polished: Aggressive cleaning removes surface metal, creates unnatural shine

whizzing.description: Use of rotating wire brush to simulate mint luster on circulated coins
signs: Unnatural 'sheen' instead of true cartwheel luster effect
Fine scratches or grooves disrupting original design details
Lettering, hairlines, and stars appear less sharp
Soft or blurred fine details from metal removal
Directional marks inconsistent with minting process
whizzing.gradingImpact: Labeled as 'Altered Surfaces' or 'Cleaned' - not eligible for numeric grade
whizzing.detection: Easily spotted by experts due to distorted lettering and design details

tooling.description: Smoothing fields to remove damage or restoring lost details with graver or knife

types.fieldSmoothing: Removing scratches, corrosion, or damage from coin fields

tooling.gradingImpact: Cannot be hidden. Coins labeled 'OBV TOOLED' or 'REV TOOLED' as appropriate.

artificialToning.description: Chemical application to create appearance of natural toning, often to hide problems
signs: Colors inconsistent with natural toning patterns
Toning may hide underlying hairlines or cleaning
Can worsen or change over time as chemicals continue reacting
artificialToning.gradingImpact: Coins with artificial toning refused numeric grade by major services

types: PVC damage - greenish residue from improper storage

gradingTips.lighting: Position light at 45 degrees and slowly rotate coin. Watch how light plays across surface. Breaks in luster indicate wear.
gradingTips.magnification: Use 5x-10x magnification for surface examination. 5x is standard for MS-70 verification.
gradingTips.comparison: Compare to reference images at same grade level. PCGS Photograde has 2,580 high-resolution photos.
gradingTips.edgesFirst: Start by examining edges and rims for dents, bumps, or defects. Work clockwise from outer fields inward.
gradingTips.bothSides: Note wear, hairlines, bag marks, cleaning, and defects on both obverse and reverse.
gradingTips.focusWeight: Most coins weight obverse more heavily (2/3 for Morgan dollars). Major focal points matter most.
